headline: How major US stock indexes fared Tuesday, 10/14/2025
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 0.4%, and the Nasdaq composite dropped 0.8%. China says it's banning dealings by Chinese companies with five subsidiaries of South Korean shipbuilder Hanwha Ocean, swiping at President Donald Trump's efforts to rebuild the industry in America. On Tuesday: The S&P 500 fell 10.41 points, or 0.2%, to 6,644.31.

On Tuesday: The S&P 500 fell 10.41 points, or 0.2%, to 6,644.31.

headline: Equinix (EQIX): Evaluating Valuation After New SAP Managed Services Collaboration With NetApp and Broadcom
summary: Equinix (EQIX) has teamed up with NetApp, Broadcom, and Kochasoft to launch a managed service tailored for SAP S/4HANA and SAP legacy workloads. This move comes as many SAP clients prepare for critical support changes and look for modern infrastructure. See our latest analysis for Equinix. Equinix’s new SAP-focused partnership comes as the company navigates an eventful year. headline: Dow Turns Higher After Falling More Than 600 Points
summary: The blue-chip index was up 200 points, or 0.4%, after falling more than 600 points, or 1.3%, at its low.  Only 11 of the Dow's 30 stocks were falling, but Goldman Sachs, alone, was shaving 65 points off the index after reporting quarterly results.

headline: The Market Selloff That Wasn’t
summary: The three major stock market indexes were all in the red as of late Tuesday morning.  The S&P 500, a market-cap weighted index, was down about 0.5%, dragged lower by losses in megacap techs (and artificial intelligence darlings) such as Nvidia, Oracle, Broadcom and Arista Networks.  Wells Fargo was a top gainer in the index following solid earnings. Ditto for Domino’s Pizza, a recent Barron’s stock pick. Casino stocks MGM Resorts, Las Vegas Sands and Wynn Resorts were rallying too, as were Airbnb and retailers Walmart and Dollar Tree.

raw.headline: The Market Selloff That Wasn’t
raw.summary: The three major stock market indexes were all in the red as of late Tuesday morning.  The S&P 500, a market-cap weighted index, was down about 0.5%, dragged lower by losses in megacap techs (and artificial intelligence darlings) such as Nvidia, Oracle, Broadcom and Arista Networks.  Wells Fargo was a top gainer in the index following solid earnings. Ditto for Domino’s Pizza, a recent Barron’s stock pick. Casino stocks MGM Resorts, Las Vegas Sands and Wynn Resorts were rallying too, as were Airbnb and retailers Walmart and Dollar Tree.
